III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4124 Communication
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a written policy regarding
Description communication that ensures that a child is able to communicate
with family and friends in a manner appropriate to the child’s
functioning and consistent with the child’s treatment plan and
security level.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was forced to talk about something in therapy they did not
want to. Youth later placed a bag over their head and went back to
their room. The youth was found with a bag over their head. Youth
is not allowed visitors and will have to restart the program.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Youth A’s Mother (Mother) was interviewed via
phone on 11/30/23. Mother reported after the incident occurred
with the bag, Youth A was not allowed visitors, which is against
the court order for visitation. Mother reported Youth A doesn’t
want to be at the facility and is upset she must start the program
over. Mother reported Youth A is forced to talk in therapy and
wants to “pummel [Therapist 1] to a pulp”.
Therapist 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/4/23. Therapist 1 reported in a therapy session on 11/2/23,
Youth A disclosed she sexually abused her brother. Therapist 1
told Youth A she had to report it to MDHHS, which caused Youth
A to become upset. As a result, Therapist 1 put her on 10-minute
safety checks for the night, but no incidents occurred. The
following morning (Friday 11/3/23), staff completed a suicide
screening with Youth A before school, and there was no risk
determined. Youth A went to school and there were no issues at
school. Youth A came back to the facility after school and was fine
for about an hour. However, at around 4-4:30 pm, staff completed
a safety check on Youth A in her room and she had a bag over
her head with a string tied around her neck. Therapist 1 reported
staff took Youth A to Helen DeVos Children’s Hospital for
evaluation, and she was approved for inpatient hospitalization.
Therapist 1 reported Youth A did not go into inpatient
hospitalization until the following day (Saturday 11/4/23).
Therapist reported Mother was notified of the incident by Therapist
2 on 11/3/23 at 9:45 pm. Therapist 1 reported youth never go
“backwards” in their program, and Youth A does not have to
restart the program. Therapist 1 reported she isn’t sure where
anyone got the impression Youth A would have to start over.
Therapist 1 reported she isn’t sure why anyone would state Youth
2

A wasn’t allowed visits, because it is not accurate. Therapist 1
reported Youth A was in inpatient hospitalization at the time of the
normal visit, so the visit was cancelled. Therapist 1 reported
Mother and Stepfather went to the hospital to visit Youth A
unauthorized and unsupervised, which is not allowed per court
order. Therapist 1 reported afterwards, Youth A stated Mother and
Stepfather are “shady” and never follow the rules, so she no
longer wanted to see Mother. Therapist 1 reported Youth A has
not seen Mother face to face since then, per her own choice,
which is Youth A’s decision according to the court order.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via
phone on 12/5/23. FCW reported the day after the therapy
session, Youth A called FCW to ask if she would still be able to
visit with her brothers after what she disclosed in therapy, and
FCW told Youth A she didn’t know yet, so they would have to talk
about it at another time. Later that night, FCW received
information from the facility Youth A was found with a bag over her
head and a string around her neck during one of their room
checks. Staff informed FCW they ripped the bag from Youth A’s
head to allow her to breathe. FCW met with Youth A on 11/30/23,
after these allegations came in, and Youth A told her she was not
forced to talk about anything in therapy. Youth A told FCW she
voluntarily discussed her history in a therapy session with
Therapist 1 and was not prompted. FCW reported she was never
told anything about Youth A being required to restart the program
because of this incident. FCW reported after the incident, Youth A
was hospitalized for a few days. FCW reported Youth A normally
has a parenting visit with Mother on Monday, but Youth A was still
in the hospital stabilizing, so the visit was cancelled. FCW
reported Mother and Stepfather showed up at the hospital and
had an unauthorized and unsupervised visit with Youth A. FCW
reported Mother is not allowed to have unsupervised visits and
Stepfather isn’t allowed visits at all, so this shouldn’t have
happened. FCW reported Youth A was upset during the visit
because Mother and Stepfather were trying to convince her to
leave the hospital and showed up without permission. Afterwards,
Youth A reported she didn’t want to see Mother anymore. FCW
reported Youth A has not seen Mother for a month, which is per
her own choice, and is allowed by the court order.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/18/23. Youth A reported she has never been forced to talk
about anything in therapy, and Therapist 1 does the opposite by
explaining she doesn’t have to talk about anything she doesn’t
want to. Youth A reported she told Mother she couldn’t have
3

visitors as an excuse because she wanted Mother to leave her
alone. Youth A reported she is allowed to make the choice not to
see Mother per the court order and hasn’t wanted to see her.
Youth A reported Mother told her she would have to restart the
program, which upset her. However, Youth A assumed Mother
might be lying, so she asked Therapist 1 the following day and
Therapist 1 confirmed she would not have to restart the program.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Berrien County Court Order dated 6/27/23 states [Youth A]
may have parenting visits at her discretion.
• None of the emails or incident notifications reviewed noted
anything about restricting Youth A’s visitations or her being
required to restart the program.
• Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Services Plan for
Resident Care Policy (rev. 06/2023) outlines the Maple
Lodge program, performance improvement, process for
assessment of youth, program focus, admission steps and
ongoing treatment steps. No where in the document does it
state youth will have to restart the program for any
circumstances. The document also outlines parent
visitation. It notes all visits and passes may occur arranged
by the treatment team under the following conditions: it’s in
the best interest of the resident, the resident has
demonstrated safe behavior, the visit is not prohibited by
the referring agency or court order.
• Therapist 1 has one disciplinary record in her employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Therapist 1 completed policy
training on 11/4/22.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. Youth A reported she has never been
forced to talk about anything in therapy. There is also no evidence
to support Youth A was told she could not have visits. Youth A
reported she told Mother she couldn’t have visits as an excuse,
because she didn’t want to see her. In addition, it was established
Youth A would not have a visitation with Mother while she was in
inpatient hospitalization. However, the decision is in line with the
facility’s policy surrounding parental visitation as Youth A was not
demonstrating safe behavior and it wasn’t assessed to be in the
best interest of Youth A. Since her hospitalization, Youth A has
chosen not to have parent visits with Mother, which is her decision
according to the court order regarding parental visitation. Youth A
4

reported Mother is the one who told her she would have to restart
the program, but Therapist 1 confirmed with Youth A (at the time)
and Consultant (during this investigation) they don’t restart
programming for any youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth’s toe was swollen, and she did not receive medical care for
a month. Youth also had a near-drowning experience and was not
taken for medical care until a week and a half after the incident,
even though she was experiencing trouble breathing. Youth is on
too many medications and parental consent was not obtained for
medications.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Youth A’s Mother (Mother) was interviewed via
phone on 11/30/23. Mother reported Youth A’s foot was stepped
on by a worker at the facility and her toe was swollen for a month.
Mother reported she and Youth A requested medical care for a
month before Youth A was seen by a doctor. Mother reported
when the facility finally took her to the doctor, the doctor said there
was nothing he could do. Mother reported this summer, Youth A
had a near-drowning experience at a pool, and she wasn’t taken
to a doctor until a week and a half later. Mother reported Youth A
has asthma and Youth A reported her head was fuzzy and she
was having trouble breathing for the week leading up to seeing the
doctor. Mother reported the only reason Youth A was seen by the
doctor was because Mother begged for it to happen. Mother
reported Youth A is on too many medications and she never
provided consent for Youth A to be on any medications. Mother
does not feel the medications are warranted and Youth A doesn’t
feel she needs all the medications. Mother reported due to all of
this, Youth A doesn’t feel safe at the facility. Mother reported she
is supposed to receive all medical information about Youth A but
hasn’t received any in a while.
Therapist 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/4/23. Therapist 1 reported Youth A has not had any breathing
issues related to water activities. Therapist 1 reported Youth A has
gone to the YMCA 2-3 times per week since March 2023 and
swims almost every time. Therapist 1 reported Youth A went on a
5

trip to Michigan Adventures over the summer and there were no
reported incidents or concerns after the trip. However, during the
next parenting visit, Youth A told Mother she almost drowned in
the wave pool and had to be pulled out by staff. Therapist 1
reported she didn’t hear about this concern after the parenting
time. More than 24 hours after the visit, Mother emailed Therapist
1 and said, “she almost drowned and needs to be taken to urgent
care ASAP”. Therapist 1 reported the email was sent on a
weekend and she doesn’t work weekends, so she didn’t receive it
until the following Monday. Therapist 1 reported the nursing
department completed an assessment on Youth A the same day
she received the email from Mother, and there were no concerns
with her breathing. Therapist 1 reported she sent an email to
Mother notifying her Youth A was examined and there were no
concerns. Therapist 1 reported she has no idea what happened to
Youth A’s toe or when it happened because Youth A never said
anything to staff about it hurting or bothering her. Therapist 1
reported Youth A told Mother during a parenting time her toe was
swollen. Therapist 1 reported FCW told her about the concern
after the parenting time and Therapist 1 agreed to have the
nursing department examine Youth A. Therapist 1 reported the
nursing department examined Youth A and the doctor instructed
Youth A to wrap her toe, ice it, and take Tylenol as needed for
pain, so they followed those instructions. Therapist 1 reported
when it didn’t get better, they took Youth A to urgent care and an
x-ray was completed. Therapist 1 reported the x-ray showed the
toe was not broken or fractured, so the recommendations for
treatment remained the same. Therapist 1 reported Youth A
wasn’t walking differently, and her toe injury didn’t seem to be
affecting her daily functioning. Therapist 1 reported Youth A tends
to be delayed in reporting issues and concerns, so they seem to
be coming up randomly, and after the fact, during conversations
with staff members or Mother. Therapist 1 reported Mother hasn’t
consented to medications because there is a court order stating
MDHHS can consent to mental health treatment, including
medications. Therapist 1 reported Mother has a history of refusing
to sign for necessary services and medications for Youth A, which
is why the court order exists.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via
phone on 12/5/23. FCW reported there is a court order allowing
MDHHS to sign for medications because Mother has repeatedly
refused to sign paperwork for services and medication. FCW
reported she supervises parenting times between Youth A and
Mother. During one of the visits (unsure of which date), Youth A
told her mother her foot hurt. FCW reported during the visit, Youth
6

A had 4-inch heels on and was running in them during the visit.
When Youth A took the heels off, she complained her toe hurt and
it was swollen at the time. FCW reported Youth A then told Mother
a staff member (didn’t say who) stepped on her foot and she
thought her toe was broken. Mother said she thought it was
broken too because it was swollen. FCW reported she reached
out to Therapist 1 within the next day or two and asked the facility
to have Youth A’s toe examined. FCW reported when Youth A
saw the nurse, it was determined it was not broken and they
wrapped it. FCW reported Youth A also had an x-ray, which
determined it wasn’t broken. FCW reported Youth A never
disclosed when a staff member stepped on her foot, so it is
unknown the length of time between when it happened and when
Youth A reported it during the parenting time. FCW reported Youth
A was examined timely, and it did not take a month. FCW reported
during another parenting visit, Youth A told Mother during the
Michigan Adventure trip over the summer, she “almost drowned”.
FCW reported Youth A stated she fell in the wave pool and water
covered her face. FCW reported Youth A went to Michigan
Adventure on a Saturday and it was the following Thursday when
Youth A complained. Mother stated she needed to be medically
examined to determine if there was fluid in her lungs because she
has breathing difficulties. The day after the parenting time, FCW
called Therapist 1 and requested an exam. FCW reported the
facility completed the exam timely and there were no findings.
FCW reported she informed Mother of the findings from both
situations.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 12/8/23. Staff 1 reported
he was not around Youth A during most of the Michigan
Adventure trip this past summer. Staff 1 reported he was never
told by Youth A or any other staff members Youth A had any
incidents during the water park trip.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 12/5/23. Staff 2 reported
she was with Youth A the entire time she was at Michigan
Adventures, which included the water park. Staff 2 reported Youth
A had no incidents in the water park, never went under water in
the wave pool, never came up gasping for air and did not
complain of any trouble breathing or her head being fuzzy after
the trip. Staff 2 reported Youth A did complain of a small migraine
after doing some laps in the wave pool, but nothing else. Staff 2
reported while they were in the water park, there was a child who
had to be pulled out of the wave pool due to a near-drowning
incident while they were present, but that child had no association
to the facility.
7

Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 12/14/23. Staff 3 reported
she went to Michigan Adventures with Youth A on 7/13/23. Staff 3
reported she was around Youth A the entire time Youth A was in
the wave pool. Staff 3 reported Youth A was in the wave pool for a
while and then came over to Staff 3 and stated, “I almost
drowned”. Staff 3 reported she was watching Youth A the entire
time and she never showed any signs of almost drowning (i.e.
sputtering water, coughing, flailing her arms, panicking, etc.). Staff
3 reported at one point she was holding Youth A’s hand in the
wave pool, but she never pulled Youth A out of the water.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/18/23. Youth A reported her toe was swollen and hurt for 2
months, but she told staff members at the facility and someone
from nursing addressed it. Youth A reported she received an x-ray
and there was nothing wrong. Youth A couldn’t remember if she
took medicine or what the actual issue with her toe was. Youth A
reported everyone at the facility made sure her toe was taken care
of appropriately and no one neglected her or left it unaddressed.
Youth A reported she doesn’t remember telling Mother about her
toe until after all the care and the x-ray was done, so she would be
able to tell Mother everything was fine. Youth A reported this past
summer she was on a trip to Michigan Adventures and was in the
wave pool. She reported she didn’t know how wave pools worked,
so she went into the deepest end of the pool. She reported when
the waves started coming, she didn’t know how to react. Youth A
stated water splashed in her face and caused her to go under
water. Youth A reported she was underwater, then came up for a
breath and this repeated multiple times for about a minute until a
staff member (she couldn’t remember who), pulled her out of the
water. Youth A reported she went back in the wave pool multiple
times afterwards because it was fun, and she wasn’t scared.
Youth A reported when she arrived back at the facility, a staff
member (she couldn’t remember who) asked her if she felt any
sloshing in her lungs, if her stomach hurt or if her throat hurt.
Youth A reported she told staff members she was completely fine
besides a small headache and a sunburn, so she didn’t need to
see a doctor. Youth A reported she feels safe at the facility.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Berrien County Court Order dated 3/24/23 gives MDHHS to
authorize, request and consent to all recommended mental
health treatment, including psychotropic medications for
[Youth A].
8

• Email from Mother to Therapist 1 dated 7/15/23 (Saturday).
Mother stated she was notified by [Youth A] during their
visit she went to a water park and staff had to pull her out of
the water because she was slightly drowning and ingested
a lot of water. Mother requested information as to why an
incident report was not completed and why she was not
notified. Mother requested [Youth A] be seen by a medical
professional ASAP due to coughing, possible water in her
lungs and tiredness.
• Nursing Note authored by Nurse 1 dated 7/17/23. Nurse 1
met with Youth A regarding the alleged drowning incident.
Youth A told Nurse 1 she was in the wave pool and almost
drowned because she was caught up in the waves, but
Staff 3 saved her by pulling her to the side of the pool.
Youth A noted she swallowed some water, but “I’ve had
water in my lungs before and I don’t feel like I have any
there now”. Youth A denied difficulty breathing, denied
coughing, and denied shortness of breath. Nurse 1 noted
no concerns or follow-up needed.
• Email from FCW to Therapist 1 dated 9/29/23 requesting
Youth A be seen for her toe being hurt or possibly broken.
FCW noted on the day of Youth A complaining about it,
Youth A was standing, walking, and running without issues.
• Nursing Note authored by Nurse 2 dated 10/3/23. Nurse 2
noted Youth A reported someone stepped on her left pinky
toe about two and a half months ago, and it has not gotten
better since then. Nurse 2 reported Youth A’s toe was
slightly swollen, so she taped her two last toes together and
encouraged Youth A to continue taping them for the next 1-
2 weeks.
• Nursing Note authored by Nurse 2 dated 10/13/23 stating
Youth A continues to report toe pain despite taping her toes
together. Nurse 2 noted Youth A’s toe was slightly red and
swollen. Nurse 2 requested an x-ray be completed.
• Incident Report sent to FCW by Therapist 1 dated 10/13/23
stating Youth A was taken to urgent care for an x-ray due to
toe pain. X-rays were noted to be normal with no tissue or
joint concerns.
• Doctor Note authored by Physician Assistant (PA) dated
10/16/23 notes x-ray of Youth A’s left foot is negative for
9

any osseous/joint abnormalities. PA noted Youth A should
follow up with staff is toe is still bothersome.
• Doctor Note authored by PA dated 10/18/23 notes toe
looks slightly red and a small amount of inflamed tissue on
nail border. PA notes there is suspicion of a slight skin
infection and possible ingrown toenail. PA provided
recommendations for treatment moving forward.
• Doctor Note authored by PA dated 10/26/23 notes redness
and swelling have improved. Youth A noted pain is
resolved. PA noted Youth A was educated not to “pick” off
nails, and how to cut nails to avoid issues in the future.
• Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Services Maple South
Health Services Policy (rev. 02/2023) outlines the
procedures for health screening, routine, and emergency
medical, dental, vision, and behavioral health care for
youth. In the event an emergent issue cannot wait until
General Medical Services can see the youth, care will be
sought at urgent care, or the emergency room as deemed
necessary. Recommendations for follow-up care will be
addressed on the campus or by referral. All requests by
youth for further medical attention will be referred to the
program nurse for assessment/follow-up. Residents will be
seen after the first 45 days of the youth’s placement to
review psychiatric needs, prescriptions and/or adjustments
of medication/dosage as needed. All subsequent reviews
will be at intervals determined by the psychiatrist.
• Residential Updated Service Plan regarding Youth A dated
10/21/23 states Youth A had a medication review on
10/2/23. It should be noted Mother was not present virtually
or physically for the appointment. At the appointment, she
was discontinued from one medication because there was
no psychiatric indication to continue the medication. Two
other medication dosages were increased because of
assessment of Youth A’s mental health status during the
appointment. Youth is prescribed a total of four medications
to address her multiple diagnoses.
• Therapist 1 has one disciplinary record in her employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Therapist 1 completed policy
training on 11/4/22.
10

Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. Youth A reported she told staff
members at the facility about her toe injury, and they addressed it
quickly and appropriately. According to Therapist 1 and FCW,
Youth A did not report her toe injury to anyone until she told
Mother at a visitation. FCW notified Therapist 1 late in the
afternoon on Friday 9/29/23 and Youth A was assessed as well as
treated for the injury multiple times between 10/3/23-10/26/23.
Any delay in treatment appears to be a result of Youth A not
reporting her injury timely.
According to Therapist 1, FCW, Staff 2 and Staff 3, Youth A did
not report an alleged near-drowning incident to anyone until she
told Mother at a visitation. Mother notified Therapist 1 on Saturday
7/15/23, and Youth A was assessed by medical staff on Monday
7/17/23. Staff 2 and Staff 3 were present with Youth A during the
Michigan Adventures trip and both reported Youth A did not have
a near-drowning experience, and no one had to pull her out of the
water.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker is allowed to consent for
psychotropic medications per a court order dated March 2023.
Therefore, Mother is not required to consent for medications.
Youth A had a medication review on 10/2/23 and her medications
were altered based on the psychiatric assessment conducted.
There is no evidence to prove Youth A is on too many
medications.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & ACT 116 722.112e Personal restraint or seclusion; release;
Section documentation; record; notification; debriefing; report of
Description serious occurrence; annual report.
(14) Each child caring institution subject to this section and
sections 2c and 2d shall report each serious occurrence to the
department. The department shall make the reports available to
the designated state protection and advocacy system upon
request of the designated state protection and advocacy system.
Serious occurrences to be reported include a minor child’s death,
a serious injury to a minor child, and a minor child’s suicide
attempt. Staff shall report any serious occurrence involving a
minor child by no later than close of business of the next business
day after a serious occurrence. The report shall include the name
of the minor child involved in the serious occurrence; a description
of the occurrence; and the name, street address, and telephone
number of the child caring institution. The child caring institution
shall notify the minor child’s parent or legal guardian and the
11

appropriate state or local government agency that has
responsibility for the minor child if the minor child is under the
supervision of the child caring institution as a result of an order of
commitment by the family division of circuit court to a state
institution or otherwise as soon as possible and not later than 24
hours after the serious occurrence. Staff shall document in the
minor child’s record that the serious occurrence was reported to
both the department and the state-designated protection and
advocacy system, including the name of the person to whom
notification of the incident was reported. A copy of the report shall
be maintained in the minor child’s record, as well as in the incident
and accident report logs kept by the child caring institution.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth’s parents were not notified within 24 hours of a suicide
attempt and serious injuries.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Youth A’s Mother (Mother) was interviewed via
phone on 11/30/23. Mother reported the incident with Youth A
putting a bag over her head at the facility happened on a
Wednesday or Thursday, but she wasn’t notified until Saturday.
Mother reported she is being notified about incidents well after
they have occurred, and she is concerned one day she is going to
get a call her daughter is dead well after the fact. Mother reported
she is supposed to be receiving all incident reports but isn’t
receiving them.
Therapist 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/4/23. Therapist 1 reported at around 4-4:30 pm on Friday
11/3/23, staff completed a safety check on Youth A in her room
and she had a bag over her head with a string tied around her
neck. Therapist reported Mother was notified of the incident by
Therapist 2 on 11/3/23 at 9:45 pm. Therapist 1 noted the email
notification sent to Youth A’s Mother was general because FCW
has reported she will pass along the full details to Mother due to
Mother’s hostility and aggression towards the facility. Therapist 1
reported she was unable to notify Mother about Youth A’s toe
injury or alleged “near-drowning” incident because Youth A didn’t
disclose either of those issues to anyone until she told Mother at
parenting visits.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via
phone on 12/5/23. FCW reported Therapist 1 asked if
notifications to Mother could go through FCW due to Mother being
aggressive and non-compliant with the facility. FCW agreed and
this process started a few months ago. FCW reported she has
12

provided information to Mother regarding any major incidents.
FCW reported she knows the facility has continued to notify Youth
A’s Mother as well because she’s seen some of the emails. FCW
reported Youth A’s suicide attempt with the bag over her head
occurred on a Friday, and Mother was notified the same night.
FCW reported she was unable to notify Mother about Youth A’s
toe injury or alleged “near-drowning” incident because Youth A
didn’t disclose either of those issues to anyone until she told
Mother at parenting visits.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via phone on 12/20/23. Therapist
2 was the on-call therapist who handled the incident with Youth A
putting a bag over her head. Therapist 2 reported he notified
Mother via email within hours of the incident occurring. Therapist 2
reported Mother never replied to his email.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Email from FCW to Therapist 1 dated 8/1/23 confirming the
facility can notify FCW about incidents and FCW will be the
middle person and provide the information to Mother.
• Email from Mother to Therapist 1 dated 7/15/23 (Saturday).
Mother stated she was notified by [Youth A] during their
visit she went to a water park and staff had to pull her out of
the water because she was slightly drowning and ingested
a lot of water. Mother requested information as to why an
incident report was not completed and why she was not
notified. Mother requested [Youth A] be seen by a medical
professional ASAP due to coughing, possible water in her
lungs and tiredness.
• Email from FCW to Therapist 1 dated 7/18/23 stating she
would inform Youth A’s Mother of the results of the nursing
visit results for the alleged drowning incident.
• Email from FCW to Therapist 1 dated 9/29/23 requesting
Youth A be seen for her toe being hurt or possibly broken.
FCW noted on the day of Youth A complaining about it,
Youth A was standing, walking, and running without issues.
• Email dated 11/3/23 from Therapist 2 notifying FCW about
the Youth A’s suicide attempt with the bag over her head
